children.name: For which structures M is the following problem decidable: Given a sentence of first-order logic φ, is φ is true in M?
keywords: For which structures M is the following problem decidable: Given a sentence of first-order logic φ, is φ is true in M?

children.name: arithmetic
Theorem. The first-order theory of (ℕ, +, ×) is undecidable.
keywords: Theorem. The first-order theory of (ℕ, +, ×) is undecidable.

children.name: arithmetic proof sketch
Proof sketch. We can use numbers to represent lists of numbers.
keywords: Proof sketch. We can use numbers to represent lists of numbers.

children.name: First-order logic can define operations such as head, or concatenation.
keywords: First-order logic can define operations such as head, or concatenation.

children.name: A list can represent a computation of a Turing machine.
keywords: A list can represent a computation of a Turing machine.

children.name: Using the list operations, one can formalize in first-order logic the statement “there exists an accepting computation”.
keywords: Using the list operations, one can formalize in first-order logic the statement “there exists an accepting computation”.
arithmetic proof sketch

children.name: In fact, undecidability holds already for ∃* formulas:
keywords: In fact, undecidability holds already for ∃* formulas:

keywords: Theorem. [DPLM] Hilbert’s 10-th problem is undecidable: Input. a polynomial Question.

children.name: There is a polynonial P such that x is a prime number iff
keywords: There is a polynonial P such that x is a prime number iff

arithmetic

children.name: Tarski arithmetic
Theorem. [Tarski 1929] The first-order theory of (ℝ, +, ×) is decidable.
keywords: Theorem. [Tarski 1929] The first-order theory of (ℝ, +, ×) is decidable.

children.name: Tarski’s proof used quantifier elimination:
keywords: Tarski’s proof used quantifier elimination:

children.name: Main lemma. For every first-order formula φ(x1, ... xn), one can compute an equivalent quantifier-free formula in (ℝ, +, ×, –, ≤, 0, 1, )
keywords: Main lemma. For every first-order formula φ(x1, ... xn), one can compute an equivalent quantifier-free formula in (ℝ, +, ×, –, ≤, 0, 1, )

children.name: Applying the main lemma to a formula without free variables, we compute an equivalent formula like (1 – 1 = 0 ∨ 0 > 1), whose truth can be easily decided.
keywords: Applying the main lemma to a formula without free variables, we compute an equivalent formula like (1 – 1 = 0 ∨ 0 > 1), whose truth can be easily decided.

children.name: Example 1
keywords: Example 1

children.name: This is because quantifier-free formulas are Boolean combinations of polynomial inequalities.
keywords: This is because quantifier-free formulas are Boolean combinations of polynomial inequalities.

children.name: Hence there is no formula for “x is a natural number”.
keywords: Hence there is no formula for “x is a natural number”.
Tarski arithmetic

children.name: Presburger arithmetic
Theorem. [Presburger 1929] The first-order theory of (ℕ, +) is decidable.
keywords: Theorem. [Presburger 1929] The first-order theory of (ℕ, +) is decidable.

children.name: Main lemma. For every first-order formula φ(x1, ... xn), the defined subset of ℕⁿ is semilinear, i.e it is a finite union of linear sets:
keywords: Main lemma. For every first-order formula φ(x1, ... xn), the defined subset of ℕⁿ is semilinear, i.e it is a finite union of linear sets:

keywords: Proof. The base case is the formula

children.name: Semilinear sets are closed under union, projection, and complementation.
keywords: Semilinear sets are closed under union, projection, and complementation.

children.name: Theorem. For every structure M: 1. if M is finite, then its second-order theory is PSpace complete. 2. if M is infinite, then its second-order theory is undecidable.
keywords: Theorem. For every structure M: 1. if M is finite, then its second-order theory is PSpace complete. 2. if M is infinite, then its second-order theory is undecidable.

children.name: Proof. 1. PSpace hardness is inherited from first-order logic, PSpace membership uses the naive algorithm.
keywords: Proof. 1. PSpace hardness is inherited from first-order logic, PSpace membership uses the naive algorithm.

children.name: 2. Undecidability is witnessed by formulas of the form:
keywords: 2. Undecidability is witnessed by formulas of the form:
second order logic

children.name: Monadic second-order logic
keywords: Monadic second-order logic

children.name: monadic second order logic
Example. The MSO theory of (ℕ, =) is decidable. Every formula is equivalent to a quantifier-free formula using X(x), |X| = n and |ℕ - X| = n.
keywords: Example. The MSO theory of (ℕ, =) is decidable. Every formula is equivalent to a quantifier-free formula using X(x), |X| = n and |ℕ - X| = n.

children.name: Question. [Tarski] Is the MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) decidable?
keywords: Question. [Tarski] Is the MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) decidable?

children.name: Robinson’s paper shows that the MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤, 2x) is undecidable.
keywords: Robinson’s paper shows that the MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤, 2x) is undecidable.

children.name: The weak MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable
keywords: The weak MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable

children.name: The MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable

children.name: weak mso
Weak MSO has the same syntax as MSO, but set quantification is restricted to finite sets.
keywords: Weak MSO has the same syntax as MSO, but set quantification is restricted to finite sets.

children.name: ∃X ∀x x ∈ X
keywords: ∃X ∀x x ∈ X

children.name: Theorem. [BEEVT] The weak MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable.
keywords: Theorem. [BEEVT] The weak MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable.

children.name: weak mso automata
Consider a formula φ(x, Y, Z ) of weak MSO. How do we represent the semantics of φ, which is a set of triples (number, finite set of numbers, finite set of numbers)?
keywords: Consider a formula φ(x, Y, Z ) of weak MSO. How do we represent the semantics of φ, which is a set of triples (number, finite set of numbers, finite set of numbers)?

children.name: A quantifier-free formula?
keywords: A quantifier-free formula?

children.name: A semilinear set?
keywords: A semilinear set?

children.name: An automaton!
keywords: An automaton!

children.name: triples of sets as finite words
keywords: triples of sets as finite words

children.name: Lemma. For every formula of weak MSO, one can compute a finite automaton that recognizes the corresponding set of words
keywords: Lemma. For every formula of weak MSO, one can compute a finite automaton that recognizes the corresponding set of words

children.name: weak mso automata proof
Proof. Induction on formula size.
keywords: Proof. Induction on formula size.

children.name: For the atomic formulas
keywords: For the atomic formulas

children.name: For ∨ and ¬, we use closure of regular languages under union and complementation.
keywords: For ∨ and ¬, we use closure of regular languages under union and complementation.

children.name: For ∃, we use closure of regular languages under projection:
keywords: For ∃, we use closure of regular languages under projection:

children.name: If L ⊆ (Σ × Γ)* is regular, then so is its projection π(L) ⊆ Σ*.
keywords: If L ⊆ (Σ × Γ)* is regular, then so is its projection π(L) ⊆ Σ*.

keywords: deterministic automata

children.name: nondeterministic automata, or regular expressions
keywords: nondeterministic automata, or regular expressions

children.name: If the formula alternates n times between complementation and projection, then determinization is applied n times, resulting in an n-fold exponential automaton.
keywords: If the formula alternates n times between complementation and projection, then determinization is applied n times, resulting in an n-fold exponential automaton.

children.name: ω5 represents the number 5
keywords: ω5 represents the number 5

children.name: ω5 + ω2 + 1 represents the set {0, 2, 5}
keywords: ω5 + ω2 + 1 represents the set {0, 2, 5}

children.name: not the same as 1 + ω2 + ω5 = ω5
keywords: not the same as 1 + ω2 + ω5 = ω5

children.name: Under this representation, membership x ∈ X and order can be defined in first-order logic using ordinal addition α + β

children.name: Automatic Presburger
Represent a number as a finite set, namely its binary expansion
keywords: Represent a number as a finite set, namely its binary expansion

children.name: Under this representation, there is a WMSO formula for x + y = z
keywords: Under this representation, there is a WMSO formula for x + y = z

children.name: Corollary For every formula φ(x1, ... xn) of Presburger arithmetic, the corresponding n-ary relation on binary expansions is definable in WMSO (equivalently, can be recognized by a finite automaton).
keywords: Corollary For every formula φ(x1, ... xn) of Presburger arithmetic, the corresponding n-ary relation on binary expansions is definable in WMSO (equivalently, can be recognized by a finite automaton).

children.name: The corollary would still be true if we added “x is a power of 2”
keywords: The corollary would still be true if we added “x is a power of 2”

children.name: or “x is the smallest power of 2 that divides both y and z”
keywords: or “x is the smallest power of 2 that divides both y and z”

children.name: (ℤ, +) is an example of an automatic group [Thurston, Epstein, ... 1980’s], or more generally an automatic structure [Nerode, Khoussainov 1994]
keywords: (ℤ, +) is an example of an automatic group [Thurston, Epstein, ... 1980’s], or more generally an automatic structure [Nerode, Khoussainov 1994]

children.name: Büchi mso
Theorem. [Büchi 1962] The MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable.
keywords: Theorem. [Büchi 1962] The MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable.

children.name: The proof is the same as for weak MSO, except that now we need to generalize automata from finite word to infinite words.
keywords: The proof is the same as for weak MSO, except that now we need to generalize automata from finite word to infinite words.

children.name: Büchi automata
Nondeterministic Büchi automata
keywords: Nondeterministic Büchi automata

children.name: Syntax: same as for nondeterministic finite automata.
keywords: Syntax: same as for nondeterministic finite automata.

children.name: Semantics: an ω-word is accepted if an accepting state appears ∞ often
keywords: Semantics: an ω-word is accepted if an accepting state appears ∞ often

children.name: When viewed an automaton on finite words, the language is {a, b}*
keywords: When viewed an automaton on finite words, the language is {a, b}*

children.name: When viewed a Büchi automaton, the language is {a, b}*a
keywords: When viewed a Büchi automaton, the language is {a, b}*a
Büchi automata

children.name: Büchi automata do not determinize, but they are still closed under: 1. union and intersection 2. projection 3. complementation
keywords: Büchi automata do not determinize, but they are still closed under: 1. union and intersection 2. projection 3. complementation

children.name: Büchi’s proof for item 3 used the Ramsey theorem
keywords: Büchi’s proof for item 3 used the Ramsey theorem

children.name: For more on Büchi automata, see Orna’s talk
keywords: For more on Büchi automata, see Orna’s talk

(ℝ, ≤) and (ℚ, ≤) have the same first-order theories, but different MSO theories.
keywords: (ℝ, ≤) and (ℚ, ≤) have the same first-order theories, but different MSO theories.

children.name: because both are dense linear orders without endpoints

children.name: “every set has a least upper bound”

children.name: A difficult proof, which manages to represent arithmetic on integers using order in the real numbers

children.name: Counterpoint 1. Every MSO formula φ(x) is equivalent to either “true” or “false”.
keywords: Counterpoint 1. Every MSO formula φ(x) is equivalent to either “true” or “false”.

children.name: Because every x, x’ ∈ ℝ can be mapped to each other using an order-preserving bijection of (ℝ, ≤)
keywords: Because every x, x’ ∈ ℝ can be mapped to each other using an order-preserving bijection of (ℝ, ≤)

keywords: Counterpoint 2. The MSO theory of (ℚ, ≤) is decidable.
